texts.shortText:
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are small, elongate, laterally-compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2-3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

This is a relatively large, robust and heavy-bodied species with a rounded head that is depressed behind the eyes, a wide mouth with thick lips and large eyes. There is a prominent brush-like cirri above each eye, made up of a flat stalk bearing a fringe of filaments. The dorsal fin has 30-34 spines and 5-6 rays, and has a slight notch after the third spine, but is not raised into and anterior crest. The pectoral fins are large and fleshy.

The eyes have a characteristic radiating pattern of alternating light and dark brown ‘spokes’. The rest of the body is mottled in light and dark brown, yellow and cream, arranges to form a series of seven darker brown vertical bars. There is often a large orange patch above the pectoral fins and behind the eyes.
Up to 23 cm total length, males larger than females.

Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Eastern Cape.

A predominantly night active species and hence not often seen. Usually found on rocky reefs below the intertidal and to a depth of about 20 m. Actively hunting at night but docile when approached, likely an ambush predator. During the day hidden among seaweeds and benthic invertebrates on the reef.
Stomach contents of only a few specimens have been analysed but these contained mostly amphipods and small molluscs, with one crab.

Species-specific details unknown, but all clinids are livebearers, males copulating with females and fertilizing the eggs internally with their intromittent organs. Juveniles develop inside the females’ ovaries and in most species the live young are born in spring, have a short planktonic life then settle on the bottom.
Klipfishes can be quite difficult to identify to species level but this species can be identified by its heavy build, large mouth and eyes and colour pattern.
